Description: One of the most frequently used palms across all designs. Self-cleaning, large tropical silhouette. Available in singles, doubles, and triples. Used as anchor trees and tall backdrop palms. Naturally taller than King Alexander palms. Often paired with Kentopsis palms in alternating rows to create varied height lines.

Short, bushy understory palm reaching 10-12 feet. Kept natural and full rather than heavily trimmed. Triples preferred. Creates a soft, palmy, bushy privacy buffer. Only trimmed twice a year. Brought in at 25-gallon size when half-grown. Flanks centerpiece trees and adds intermediate height.

Called 'the king of palms.' Self-cleaning with gorgeous V-shape in doubles. Beautiful long fronds. Petite compared to foxtails — used as intermediate trees. Perfect in front of windows. Comes in singles, doubles, triples, quads. Doubles are the favorite for flat surfaces and front entrances.

Massive silver/blue centerpiece palm. Stunning and large. Used as a dramatic focal tree. Needs plenty of room — the fronds spread wide. Not to be crowded by other large plants. Silver tone becomes more pronounced with age.

Smooth-trunked tropical palm used as tall backdrop trees. Comes in doubles and triples. Gorgeous when mature. Paired with backing plants like lady palms. Used as inherited specimens that integrate well into new landscape designs.

Big statement palm with diamond-patterned trunk. Offers tremendous visual punch — few single trees match its impact. Currently comes with a disease disclaimer requiring proper pest control treatment a couple times per year. Not being actively planted new due to disease concerns, but beloved when inherited in landscapes.
Compact, neat, self-cleaning palm. Used for intermediate height in layered designs between pygmy dates and foxtails. Creates nice height variation when placed between larger palms.
Classic tropical icon. Used in pairs flanking beds or centerpiece palms. Provides enough shade coverage for understory plantings.

Extremely slow-growing fan palm — takes 20 years to get real size. Completely different structure and look from feather palms. Ideal as a centerpiece in front of windows or blank walls. Trunks can be softened with base plantings. Fronds loved but trunks less so — solved by planting ground cover around the base.
Beautiful fan fronds. Offers a botanical garden aesthetic. Nice, clean palms that reflect light beautifully. Found at botanical gardens and used to create that curated tropical look.

One of the designer's favorites. Dark green clustering palm excellent for privacy walls. Plant 6 feet off the house minimum. 30-gallon size recommended for immediate impact. Reaches 27-30 feet over time. Makes fantastic living walls when planted in rows. Not for pool enclosures due to spread. Creates lush, dense green backdrop.
Larger variety of fishtail palm. Single-trunked species with bigger leaves than the clustering type. Creates dramatic impact when used as a specimen tree among regular fishtails.
Gives a soft, airy look. Used as triples at corners. Grows well once fertilized with palm-specific fertilizer. Nice understory palm with a delicate, graceful silhouette.

Unique swollen trunk that's iconic and distinctive. Used in triples as accent features alongside boulders and yucca. Provides partial shade for understory plants like farfugium. Slow-growing and eye-catching.

Florida-friendly slow-growing palm maxing out at 15-16 feet. Very drought-tolerant and tough. Always remains an understory tree with a cascading umbrella canopy feel. Used for mounting bromeliads since it stays put for years.
Clustering palm often confused with Areca palms. Does produce some droppings. Used for tropical backdrop and privacy screening. Good alternative to Areca palms.

A rare palm species that's hard to find. First palm planted in the designer's personal garden. Naturally taller than many palms. Used alternating with foxtails to create varied height lines. Ideal for creating that botanical garden feel. A conversation starter.

Not actually a palm — related to bananas and birds of paradise. Flat fan shape that's architecturally stunning. Gets very large, so needs space. Used as a dramatic backdrop. Takes a couple extra days of water establishment. Creates instant tropical drama.
Tall, majestic palms seen at botanical gardens lining pathways ('Palm Alley'). Creates that classic grand tropical entrance feel. One of the larger palm species.
Distinctive hairy/fibrous trunk that gives it its common name. A cool and unique specimen palm spotted at botanical gardens. Conversation piece in any garden.
Technically not a true palm. Has a distinctive bulbous base. Can be used as a small accent or grow larger. The chunky, fat base is a design feature.

The designer's top favorite palm of all. Rare, slow-growing. Stunning compact, vertical crown that curls elegantly. Beautiful dark green trunk transitioning to a cane-roped base that opens into an elephant-foot shape at the bottom. Self-cleaning. Reaches 27-30 feet but takes many years. Handles temperatures above 32°F. A true focal point tree.

Small rare palm, very vertical with multi-trunks. Named for its beautiful white canes. Leaves stack vertically and compactly on top of one another. Unlike Areca or Cat palms, this one stays vertical rather than widening out.

Rare Cuban fan palm — a standout feature tree. Silver-toned fronds that grow more silver with age. Extremely slow-growing (about 1-1.5 feet per year). Compact, vertical crown with overlapping fronds. Heavier crown than trunk can support initially, so must be staked. A stunner at any size. Often mistaken for Bismarck. One palm that makes a complete impact on its own.

Super slow-growing palm that can eventually get very large — the specimen shown was 20 years old. Available from 15-gallon up to field-grown. A long-term investment palm. Worth the wait despite extremely slow growth.

Shade-tolerant clustering palm with distinctive fan-shaped leaves. Clumps at the base and spreads via pups. Keep under control by removing lower clumping every 3-4 months. Maintained in a bouquet style rather than letting it spread. Interesting leaf shape that's very different from feather palms. Six-foot height ideal for mid-garden accents.
Mentioned in botanical garden context. A stately palm with large fan leaves.

Large, dramatic bromeliad. Changes color based on light — more purple in full sun, more green in shade. Can handle full sun. Holds water in cups from above which needs to be sprayed out every couple weeks to prevent stagnation. Used as vertical accent features and statement pieces. Produces pups for propagation.
Sun-tolerant bromeliad — handles direct sun and pavement bounce-back heat like a champ. Flamboyant green and yellow coloring with pink tips. Paired beautifully with darker bromeliads for contrast.

Dark, dark-toned Neoregelia variety. Very tough and sun-loving. Holds a pink coloring rather than orange flame. In the Neo family. Paired with Johannis for a light/dark contrast effect. Can be mounted on trees at an angle to prevent mosquito breeding.

Large canopy bromeliad — 15-gallon plants available. Root ball can be cut down dramatically because bromeliads don't rely heavily on root systems. Epiphytic nature means minimal root ball is needed for planting.

Red/fire-colored small bromeliad ideal for mounting on trees. Best mounted with fence staples rather than ribbon, which stretches and loosens. Favorite method is to mount at a slight angle for drainage.
Bright lemon-lime colored bromeliad used for tree mounting. Provides vivid color contrast when mounted on palm trunks.

Compact dwarf croton with twisted, colorful leaves. Stays small and rounded — perfect for lower layers. Can remain the same size forever if desired. Best brought in at 7 or 10-gallon size for immediate impact with dwarf varieties. A go-to plant for adding pops of color.
Classic large croton with bold yellow, orange, and red foliage. Stunning color especially with some sun protection. Used as backdrop color pops alongside boulders and accent palms.

Related to mammy crotons but with broader banana-like leaves. Dwarf variety grows super slow in tight areas. Offers nice pops of color from the road without getting in the way. Stays compact together.

Compact, dense croton. Available in 7-gallon for rounded shape. Chunks out only slightly and stays small. Easy to maintain at a low height. Grows slow — ideal where slow, predictable growth is needed.
Narrow-leafed croton with fall-like coloring (more oranges). During summer shows more reds and yellows. Grows to about 4 feet tall. Great for clustering near house walls.
Larger croton that thrives in filtered light/shade. Hard to find colorful plants for shade gardens — these deliver. Used in 7-gallon size to encompass the base of taller plantings.
Yellow-speckled compact croton. Used as underskirt planting beneath taller copper leaves and shrubs.

Most frequently used copper leaf variety. Fire-touched coloring. Gets about 5 feet tall. Used extensively as mid-layer planting and front-of-border color. Pairs beautifully with darker plants. Wraps around corners and creates sweeps of warm color.

Deep red copper leaf that creates privacy buffer growing 8-10 feet if left to grow. Trimmed twice a year back to 4 feet. Four 7-gallon plants create a solid wall of color. Gets a little stemmy at the bottom — always use an underskirt planting.
White/light copper leaf variant. Creates softness and brightness. Used as a transition between dark and colorful plantings. Staggered at 2 feet on center so plants fully connect.
Variegated copper leaf related to Louisiana Red. Used as backdrop groupings creating colorful walls. Multiple color variations available.
Dark red/rojo copper leaf variety. Used as backdrops and corner plantings. Gorgeous fire-toned color that makes it a year-round showstopper.
Textured copper leaf with distinctive curling leaves. Adds a different dimension to copper leaf groupings.

Go-to hedge plant. Dense from bottom to top with no openings — stays solid throughout. Grows faster than buttonwood so requires more trimming. Thins slightly in shade so needs extra fertilizing in low-light areas. Used extensively as rear backdrop hedging. Seen throughout the Florida Keys. Can be maintained at any height.

Florida's answer to northern boxwood. Formal, compact, shiny green leaf. Emerald Blanket variety is on the smaller side. Used both as hedging and as individual rounded ground cover in groupings. Maintained individually rather than as one solid hedge for a more organic look. 'Florida boxwood' — very formal, very controlled.

Florida native that's underrated. Can be kept at 3 feet or let to grow to 20 feet. Makes a fabulous dense hedge. Salt-tolerant — perfect for coastal areas. Doesn't grow as fast as Clusia so less maintenance. Stays solid from bottom to top. No beautiful blooms but tough, reliable, and resilient to pests. Attracts birds.
Silver foliage version of buttonwood. Provides beautiful contrast against green plantings. Used along curved walkways and as hedge lines. One silver element can really pop against a lot of greens.

Dwarf native viburnum that's become a new favorite. Gorgeous white flowers. Super compact shape that stays small without heavy trimming. Blooms all spring, summer, and into fall. Handles temperatures well below freezing — good all the way to Jacksonville. Used as dark green border framing. Natural soft boxwood-type look.
Dense hedge option — denser than many alternatives. Can be shaped and maintained like buttonwood. Used as privacy screening and formal hedging.
Used in pink variety as backdrop along 8-foot walls. Red variety is a butterfly plant. Not in bloom during winter months but provides nice color backdrop during blooming season.

Multicolored tree variety with white, fuchsia, and watermelon coloring on the same plant. Requires maintenance as it can grow vigorously. Used as accent trees and wall coverings. Loves BGI bougainvillea fertilizer. Don't give too much water. Blooms prolifically with proper care.
Dwarf bougainvillea variety. Used as a half-circle accent at the base of larger bougainvillea trees. Darker pink, almost violet-colored flowers. Lower-maintenance than full-size varieties.

Botanical: Jasminum spp. (likely J. multiflorum or J. sambac dwarf)
Description: Compact with beautiful fragrance. Used as formal border plantings. About to burst into bloom in the designs shown. Wonderful jasmine scent adds a sensory layer to garden design.

Most frequently used agave-type accent. Vertical, architectural focal point. Planted about 5 feet on center in triangular formations. Frames front beds and entrances. Gives substance and draws the eye vertically. Paired with song of India for contrast. Taller variety available. Goes up and out as it matures.
Classic large blue-green agave. Used as bold anchor accent alongside dwarf pentas. Creates dramatic entrance features.
Blue-toned agave that pairs beautifully with boulders. A favorite accent for creating desert-meets-tropical vignettes.
Soft, thornless agave. Used to add gentle interest around boulders and bromeliad halos. No risk of stabbing — safe near walkways.
Smaller agave variety. Used in groups of three. Described as cute little accents — they're compact showstoppers.

A new favorite accent. Thornless — can touch leaves without problems. Silver-toned, drought-tolerant, handles cold temperatures all the way to Jacksonville. Grows super slow (4-6 inches per year). Develops a cool trunk when mature. Easy to match multiples for symmetry. Perfect in tall tubular pots along walkways.

Incredibly versatile — lives in shade, filtered light, or full sun. Beautiful yellow and green variegation (more white/green in shade). Easily kept as a compact bush by nipping the tops, which forces branching. Each trim produces two new heads. Can be trained as a tree or kept bushy forever. Used to brighten dark spots between darker plantings.
Unique spiral leaf arrangement. Available in full-size and dwarf varieties. Dwarf stays small. Used as an anchor on opposite sides of beds from palms for visual balance.
Purple-tinted tropical lily. Used in staggered triangular formations along driveways. Three plants create nice impact. Still young in the design shown but will flush out to nice size.

Large tropical lily reaching 6-7 feet. Leaves a bare stem/stock behind as it grows, which can be layered underneath with smaller plants like variegated ginger. Fills out to become broad, big, and leafy. Some people don't love the exposed stock but it creates great layering opportunities.

One of the most beloved plants across all designs. Shiny, gorgeous dark leaves. Starts compact at 3-gallon size covering the ground, then matures upright creating space for underplanting. Used wherever possible — every garden gets at least a few. Pairs with aglaonemas and copper leaves.

Super slow-growing foliage plant. Takes a very long time to develop any stemming. Used as a secondary layer beneath taller Rojo Congos. Grows in filtered light to full shade. Eventually allows room for foxtail ferns underneath as it matures. Multiple varieties mentioned including 'Maras.'
Variegated foliage provides nice contrast. Grows well as a mid-height bush. Used in the intermediate layer between palms and ground cover.

Botanical: Anthurium hookeri or A. 'Jungle King' (large landscape types)
Description: Dark-foliaged tropical used extensively as mid-height clusters. Plant 2-3 in one hole so they push against each other and form thick groupings. Creates dark contrast against brighter plantings. Very popular — frequently used alongside copper leaves, crotons, and bromeliads. Collections of them framed with Song of India brighteners. Note: exact plant uncertain from transcription — may also refer to a large Alocasia or Cordyline variety.

Split-leaf tropical. Can handle more sun than commonly thought. Two plants don't seem like a lot but they fill in dramatically. Works well with philodendrons. Leaves pop out around other garden elements for a lush jungle feel.

Tough, tried-and-true privacy plant. Handles salt, clay, well-draining soil, filtered light, and full sun. Creates a soft, wild look that tears down naturally. Quick privacy from small size/small budget. Not for formal gardens — naturally branches and widens over time. Good for 5-10 years before needing replacement.
Dwarf, compact alternative to Burle Marx philodendron. Ideal ground-space filler in medium light to full shade. More controlled and compact than Burle Marx. Burns in direct sun.

Gorgeous glossy-leafed bedding plant. Cascading and clustering growth habit — needs to be planted with companions, not isolated. Creates a beautiful sea of green jungle floor. Stays around 2.5-3 feet. Grows super slow. Perfect under trees in shade with leaf acid. A lovely anchor point plant. Alternative: Xanadu for a more compact option.

Stunning giant-leafed plant. Really branches out as it matures. Produces pups for new garden spots. Beautiful, healthy trunk base. Creates a dramatic focal point in shaded areas. Every star needs a supporting cast.
Large tropical leaves that add instant drama. Can work right in water. Used in shade to filtered light areas. Let them live naturally and fill in space.

Clusters together for a wild, dark look. The deep, dark color is dramatic. Matures quickly and fills in spaces rapidly. All the woody stems eventually get hidden as foliage fills in. Used to back centerpiece palms.

A go-to skirt and intermediate planting that the designer 'can't say enough about.' Plant 3-5 together and they thicken up into a solid dash of color. Needs some sun protection — handles morning and early afternoon sun but wilts in harsh afternoon rays. Grows faster than crotons. Trimmed twice a year. Used as the primary layer between taller accent plants and lower ground covers. Dense, thick, and colorful. Note: exact identification uncertain from transcript phonetics.

Chartreuse green foxtail-shaped fronds. The go-to lower-layer plant. Creates a swath of texture beneath taller plantings. Pairs with everything — crotons, bromeliads, agaves. Used in sweeps wherever a soft green carpet is needed.

Epiphyte — can be mounted on trees or grown at tree bases. Creates a soft, pillowy effect around palm trunks. Whole communities of them create lush green carpets in shaded areas. Used at the bottom of tree-mounted bromeliad displays.
Massive fern spotted at botanical garden — described as 'huge' and impressive.

Low-growing ground cover with blue flowers. Used at the base of stair-step planting designs as the lowest tier. Butterfly-attracting. Creates a carpet of blue color. One of the listed butterfly plants in the garden.

Brazilian Red variety is a favorite. Blooms all spring, summer, and into fall. Used in dabs/clusters of 5-6, not large sweeps. Broken with non-blooming plants between clusters. Must be trimmed — go mushroom style (taller in center, rounded at bottom). Connects into solid swaths of ground cover. Major butterfly attractor.

Multiple varieties used: yellow, fire orange, 'Ann Marie.' Always use STERILE varieties — not the ones that spread invasively. Compact versions preferred. Yellow lantana used as carpet flowers. Fire orange for warm pops. Butterfly-attracting — listed as a garden butterfly plant.

Blooms 10 months of the year — incredible flower production. Multiple colors available including Maui yellow and red varieties. Used as sweeps and swaths. Pairs with crotons and copper leaves. Great for formal front beds. One of the most reliable blooming plants in the landscape.

Deep red/burgundy ground cover. Used in seas and sweeps. Great low-growing border plant. Pairs with other compact plants. Stays mounded and offers consistent color without blooming. Never planted in straight lines — used in organic clusters.

Aggressive growing ground cover with yellow daisy-like blooms. Creates 1.5-2 foot tall carpet. Give it its own space — don't crowd with other plants. Rabbits tend to leave it alone. Really tough. Used as backdrop swaths of yellow.
Pink-flowering native ground cover. Provides color breaks between darker plantings like viburnum. Used to frame boulders and add spots of interest.

Ideal for shady garden spots — unless you have rabbits. Produces long shooting blooms that can get quite large. Mass plantings create stunning displays. Blooms in spite of being nibbled. Perfect for filtered-light garden areas.

Creates an 8-foot wall of stunning pink blooms as a backdrop. Three 15-gallon plants thicken up, fill out, and become a dense wall. Perfect for blocking two-story houses behind a property. Gets leggy at the base when young — pair with skirt plantings. One of the few plants that serves as both privacy screen and dramatic color.

Florida's version of the weeping willow. Gorgeous red bottle-brush flowers most of the year. Fans out into a mushroom-shaped canopy on a skinny trunk — perfect for layering plants underneath. Great intermediate buffer tree. Ideal in triangular formations of three. Perfect for birds and butterflies.

Stunning 'dancing blooms' from fall through spring. Gets big, so plan for space. The purple/pink flowers create a pow-wow punch at corners and endpoints. Perfect for where you need one dramatic large flowering tree.

Fluffy pink powderpuff blooms. Can get large and wild if not maintained. Almost gives a mimosa-type feel with the puffy blooms that open up. Used as flowering accent trees. Available in 25-gallon size.
Classic tropical flowering tree. Can be trained into lollipop shapes. Needs proper conditions to really thrive. Iconic tropical fragrance and flower.
Listed as a butterfly plant in the garden. Beautiful blue/purple cascading flowers that attract butterflies and pollinators.
Butterfly garden plant. Opens with puffy blooms similar to powderpuff tree. Listed among the top 10 butterfly-attracting plants.

Striking red/pink bloom that lasts for months. Blooms all summer. Needs warm climate — doesn't tolerate freezing. Use filtered light in pots to prevent harsh sun burn. Perfect for corners, pool areas, and water features. Gets hot pink when mature and going full. Protect from cold by bringing pots into garage.
Used as underplanting beneath crinum lilies and taller tropicals. Dwarf variety wraps around the base of larger plants. Engulfs the bottom layer of plantings.
Exotic tropical with dramatic flower bracts. Seen at botanical gardens and used in lush tropical plantings. Creates a Hawaii-like cluster when paired with palms and large-leafed tropicals.

Succulent flowering plant — best kept in pots for drainage control. Doesn't want too much water. Asian bonsai-like trunk when mature. Loves sun. Comes in many color varieties. Blooms all summer with proper care. Place on pedestals along walkways for pops of interest. Can be passed down to kids — lasts for years in pots. Loves bougainvillea fertilizer or osmocote.

Blooms constantly once established — hasn't stopped since planting. Needs partial shade — flourishes under palm canopies and taller plantings that provide coverage. Used at the base of bottle palms and accent features.

Grows to 5-6 feet tall. Gorgeous orange flower bloom. Naturally leans toward sunlight creating an interesting focal point. Blooms magnificently in summer — blast of orange visible from gates. Produces runners/pups so needs management. Cut back seasonally.

Native Florida plant. Compact dwarf version preferred. Stays lush, thick, and compact. Beautiful cherry-like berries. Perfect underneath tree plantings in partial shade. Great for pollinators. A wonderful native pollinator plant.
Native Florida butterfly plant. Dwarf variety used in landscape designs. Listed among the top butterfly-attracting plants for the garden.
Blue-flowering shrub that performs reliably. Existing plantings often kept in new designs because they do so well. Blue flowers complement warm-colored tropicals.
Purely ornamental — not fruit-bearing. Adds instant tropical drama with large paddle-shaped leaves.
Mounted to trees alongside bromeliads. Creates columns of draping orchids with upright bromeliads. Mounted like you would a Christmas tree decoration. Malaysian orchids spotted at botanical gardens.
Essential butterfly garden plant — specifically for Monarch butterflies. Listed as #10 in the butterfly plant collection.
Listed as a butterfly plant. Provides yellow iris flowers that attract pollinators.

Botanical: Buxus microphylla var. japonica (or similar Florida cultivar)
Description: Used as a formal, finished hedge planting. Provides that classic tight, manicured hedge look.
Used when existing in client landscapes — transplanted and incorporated into new designs. Nice green, compact form.
Existing specimens transplanted into new designs. Provides formal evergreen structure.
Variegated accent option. Mentioned alongside Java White copper leaf as a way to add brightness to darker plantings.
